description: The Cisco Cybersecurity Operations show (Exam 210-255) will help prepare someone preparing for the 2 exams of the CCNA Cyber Ops Certification.  It also aids them to get ready to begin working as an associate level analyst within a Security Operations Center (SOC) and help the candidate handle the tasks, duties and responsibilities working as an analyst in the SOC.  The show will focus on introductory-level skills of basic threat analysis, event correlation, identifying malicious activities and using a playbook for incident response.
descriptionMD: The Cisco Cybersecurity Operations show (Exam 210-255) will help prepare someone preparing for the 2 exams of the CCNA Cyber Ops Certification.  It also aids them to get ready to begin working as an associate level analyst within a Security Operations Center (SOC) and help the candidate handle the tasks, duties and responsibilities working as an analyst in the SOC.  The show will focus on introductory-level skills of basic threat analysis, event correlation, identifying malicious activities and using a playbook for incident response.
name: CCNA Cyber Ops (210-255 SECOPS)
subtitle: Cisco Cybersecurity Operations

episodes.description: The Cisco Cybersecurity Operations show (Exam 210-255) will help prepare someone preparing for the 2 exams of the CCNA Cyber Ops Certification. It also aids them to get ready to begin working as an associate level analyst within a Security Operations Center (SOC) and help the candidate handle the tasks, duties and responsibilities working as an analyst in the SOC. The show will focus on introductory-level skills of basic threat analysis, event correlation, identifying malicious activities and using a playbook for incident response.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss traditional malware detection and mitigation and the analyzing of reports to that end. Here they specifically look at using Cisco's AMP ThreatGRID suite to gather information and generate reports for analysis.
episodes.title: Read Analysis Reports

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue discussing the importance of report analysis for threat mitigation. Here they dive deeper into Cisco's AMP ThreatGRID suite, specifically its Dynamic Analysis, Network File Trajectory, Indications of Compromise, and Security Intelligence events.
episodes.title: Read Analysis Reports Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish their look at analyzing reports for threat mitigation by looking at the open-source solution, Cuckoo. Here they will look at Cuckoo's ability to create a sandbox environment for testing malware and then they show you how to submit threats for evaluation by the Antimalware establishment.
episodes.title: Read Analysis Reports Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie introduce you to the CVSS 3.0 scoring system. Here they will describe what the CVSS is and reasons for its development, how it's maintained, and its metrics. Then they will begin to explore how to calculate a Base score; looking at Exploitability Metrics like Attack Vector(AV) and Attack Complexity(AC).
episodes.title: Describe CVSS 3.0

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining how to calculate a CVSS Base score by looking at the other 2 Exploitability Metrics; Privileges Required(PR), User Interaction(UI), and the Scope using their respective metrics.
episodes.title: Describe CVSS 3.0 Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish calculating a CVSS Base score. Here they look at Impact Metrics (Confidentiality/Integrity/Availability), Temporal Metrics (Exploit-Code Maturity/Remediation Level/Report Confidence), Environmental Metrics, and Qualitative Severity Rating Scores.
episodes.title: Describe CVSS 3.0 Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the importance of filesystems when it comes to computer security. Here they dive into filesystems supported by the Windows Operating System, which includes: File Allocation Table(FAT) and New Technology File System(NTFS), as well as how we handle them in a forensically sound way.
episodes.title: Understand Windows File Systems

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the importance of filesystems when it comes to computer security. Here they dive into filesystems supported by the Windows Operating System, which includes: File Allocation Table(FAT) and New Technology File System(NTFS), as well as how we handle them in a forensically sound way. Also covered: Alternate Data Streams, MACE, EFI, and Timestamps.
episodes.title: Understand Windows File Systems Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the importance of filesystems when it comes to computer security. Here they dive into filesystems supported by the Linux Operating System, which includes: EXT3, EXT4, ReiserFS, Journaling, MBR, Swap files, HFS, and UEFI vs BIOS.
episodes.title: Understand Linux File Systems

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore how to identify, handle, and process digital forensic evidence. They start by defining some terms like "Computer Forensics", "Chain of Custody", and "Order of Volatility".
episodes.title: Identify Forensic Evidence

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore how to identify, handle, and process digital forensic evidence. Here they continue by comparing and contrasting the three types of evidence (Best/Corroborative/Indirect) as well as the two types of images (Altered/Unaltered), and finally describe the role of Attribution.
episodes.title: Identify Forensic Evidence Part 2

topics.title: Endpoint Threat Analysis and Computer Forensics

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore interpreting basic Regular Expressions, aka RegEx. Here they will give you a quick walkthrough of common RegEx functions and operators, then using that knowledge to help them filter the output of a Cisco router's configuration output down to only pertinent data.
episodes.title: Interpret Basic Regular Expressions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore interpreting basic Regular Expressions, aka RegEx. Here they continue using RegEx to filter configuration output in a Cisco router and then transition to using RegEx in Wireshark to filter conversations, drastically reducing the output to only pertinent information.
episodes.title: Interpret Basic Regular Expressions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore ethernet headers and their importance as a security vector. Here they will describe the different sections of the header, Layer 2's lack of security measures, and types of common Layer 2 attacks such as DHCP Starvation, ARP Spoofing, and CAM Table Exhaustion.
episodes.title: Describe Protocol Headers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into describing the importance of IP headers as a source of security and network information. Here they continue to breakdown the IP packet header, discussing possible security issues. They pick up with the Time-to-Live(TTL) field, Protocol Number, Checksum, and IP addresses.
episodes.title: Describe Protocol Headers Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore ethernet headers and their importance as a security vector. Here they will perform an ARP Spoofing attack, exploring and analyzing the packet capture of the attack. Then the demonstrate and analyze a DHCP Starvation attack.
episodes.title: Describe Protocol Headers Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into describing the importance of IP headers as a source of security and network information. Here they cover what's in an IP header (version, length, source&destination addresses, type of service, datagram length, don't fragment flag, more fragment flag) and IP addresses for both IPv4 and IPv6.
episodes.title: Describe IP Headers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into describing the importance of IP headers as a source of security and network information. Here they continue to breakdown the IP packet header, discussing possible security issues. They pick up with the Time-to-Live(TTL) field, Protocol Number, Checksum, and IP addresses.
episodes.title: Describe IP Headers Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into describing the importance of IP headers as a source of security and network information. Here they turn their focus toward IPv6 headers, looking at the header fields in detail and security concerns associated with them.
episodes.title: Describe IP Headers Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use and importance of ICMP from a security standpoint. Here they will define what ICMP is and how it works. Then they look at the header information associated with ICMP, analyze a packet capture of a ping sweep, and begin to talk about the ICMP types.
episodes.title: Describe ICMP Intrusion

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use and importance of ICMP from a security standpoint. Here they continue discussing ICMP types that you should be aware of and their associated attack vectors such as ICMP Source Quench and Time Exceeded.
episodes.title: Describe ICMP Intrusion Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use and importance of ICMP from a security standpoint. Here they continue discussing ICMP types that you should be aware of and their associated attack vectors. They begin by looking at a packet capture of ICMP traffic to see the different types being used. Then they explore attacks like Firewalking, OS Fingerprinting, and ICMP Route Redirects.
episodes.title: Describe ICMP Intrusion Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use and importance of ICMP from a security standpoint. Here they continue discussing ICMP types that you should be aware of and their associated attack vectors such as Router Discovery spoofing, Tunneling attack, and Denial of Service attacks like Oversized ICMP messages, ICMP floods, and Smurf attacks.
episodes.title: Describe ICMP Intrusion Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at Transport layer headers. Specific topics covered here includes: TCP Basic Operations, TCP 3-Way Handshake, and Header Fields breakdown.
episodes.title: Describe Transport Layer Headers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at Transport layer headers. Specific topics covered here includes: Packet analysis of the TCP 3-Way handshake and sequencing, Session Hijacking, and TCP Checksums.
episodes.title: Describe Transport Layer Headers Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at Transport layer headers. Specific topics covered here includes: Invalid TCP flag combinations, UDP Headers breakdown, UDP Flooding, and UDP Max length.
episodes.title: Describe Transport Layer Headers Part 3

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach describe HTTP Headers, HTTP Basics Review, GET, POST, HTTP Methods, and HEAD.
episodes.title: Describe HTTP Headers

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach cover PUT, DELETE, TRACE, OPTIONS, CONNECT, content-type, user agent, and referer field.
episodes.title: Describe HTTP Headers Part 2

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach conclude describing HTTP Headers, Cookies, Cookie Components, Double Encoding, and common character used in web attacks.
episodes.title: Describe HTTP Headers Part 3

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach discuss what is NetFlow, identify the elements from a NetFlow v5 record security event, IP-5 Tuple information, NetFlow v5 fields, and what is a Flow Record.
episodes.title: Identify Netflow v5 Records

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach cover what is a Flow Exporter, what is a Flow Monitor, how we should want to cache the information, and what is Stealth Watch.
episodes.title: Identify Netflow v5 Records Part 2

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach interrupt common artifact elements from an event to identify an alert, identify key elements in an in intrusion from a given PCAP file, extract files from a TCP stream when given a PCAP file from Wireshark, and explain Wireshark>File>extract objects
episodes.title: Examine Intrusion Events

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach go over intrusion event technologies, map the provided events to source technologies, look at DHCP Server/Exhaustion, and DNS Server.
episodes.title: Intrusion Event Technologies

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach continue talking about intrusion event technologies, NetFlow, StealthWatch, FMC (Cisco Firepower Management Center), and Statistical Data-Session Data.
episodes.title: Intrusion Event Technologies Part 2

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach conclude the discussion about intrusion event technologies, IDS/IP{S (Sguil), 5-Tuple information, Alert Data, Firewall (NGFW), Packet Capture, TOP Information, Network Application Control, Proxy Logs, Transaction Data, Extracted Data, and Identity & Access Management/Cisco ISE.
episodes.title: Intrusion Event Technologies Part 3

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach compare & contrast impact /no-impact for False Positive-False Negative-True Positive-True Negative, and define Heuristics.
episodes.title: Intrusion Impact Analysis

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach continue discussing Intrusion Impact Analysis, interpret a provided intrusion event & host profile to calculate the Impact Flag generated by FMC, explain what Firepower Management Center (FMC) is, and conclude with an FMC demo.
episodes.title: Intrusion Impact Analysis Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss incidence response plans. They describe what they are and the elements that hsould be included in them according to NIST.SP800-61 r2
episodes.title: Incident Response Elements

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss incident response plans. They link those elements discussed previously to the analysis steps in SP 800-61 r2 and identify the stake holders that also belong in each analysis category.
episodes.title: Incident Response Elements Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe CSIRT and the goals of CSIRT.  They take some time to go over the 6 goals when given a CSIRT.
episodes.title: Describe CSIRT Goals

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie help identify server profiling elements and link data types to 3 of the compliance frameworks: PCI, HIPPA and SOX.  Lastly, they also identify elements that must be protected according to PCI-DSS.
episodes.title: Identify Cybersec Elements and Frameworks

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss the process of data normalization and why we should do it. They also discuss making data values into universal format for data analysis.
episodes.title: Describe Data Normalization

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe what they 5 tuple are, as well as how they correlate in events. They also show how the 5-tuple can help to isolate and identify a compromised host in logs.
episodes.title: Describe 5 Tuple Correlation

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie look at a threat analysis report and show how to identify a possible compromised host.  They show indicators of compromise and how to drilldown to find information.
episodes.title: FirePower Management Console

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie compare and contrast deterministic and probabilistic analysis methods to help with Data and events analysis.
episodes.title: Compare and Contrast Analysis Methods

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe the use of the Diamond Model of Intrusion and how it helps us to handle events.  They also show how the Kill Chain and Diamond Model work together for a complete security intelligence model.
episodes.title: Classify and Categorize Intrusions

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe the use of the Diamond Model of Intrusion and how it helps us to handle events.  They also show how the Kill Chain and Diamond Model work together for a complete security intelligence model.
episodes.title: Classify and Categorize Intrusions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe the use of the Diamond Model of Intrusion and how it helps us to handle events.  They also show how the Kill Chain and Diamond Model work together for a complete security intelligence model.
episodes.title: Classify and Categorize Intrusions Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie take some time to look at how NIST.SP800-61 r2 incident handling process to an incident event. They break down the process and show recommended process for incident handling
episodes.title: Apply NIST.SP800-61 r2 To Events

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe Evidence Handling as documented in NIST SP800-86. They explore it's importance and key in forensics.
episodes.title: NIST SP800-86 Evidence Handling

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie apply VERIS schema categories to incident handling events.
episodes.title: Apply VERIS Schema Categories
